Antibogotes

Peeling, replying to Marc, quoted and replied:
 Quote:
 Inevitably, nihilism will expose all cherished beliefs and sacrosanct truths as symptoms of a defective Western mythos. This collapse of meaning, relevance, and purpose will be the most destructive force in history, constituting a total assault on reality and nothing less than the greatest crisis of humanity
 
 In other words, in Nietzsche's opinion it is the ultimate vacuity of the purpose offered by all institutions, including Judeo-Christianity, that sets us up for this fall.
 
 
 I would like to point out that this is not Nietzsche's own opinion. His sister Elisabeth Förster-Nietzsche edited The Will to Power after Nietzsche went into third-stage syphilis, with heavy brain damage. It is true that Nietzsche despised Christianity, but he felt that he had a higher purpose, and was never a nihilist. He was seeking a way to create the next higher form of human life, preferably as far above us mentally as we are above our reconstruction of the common chimp-human ancestors. 
 
 In fact, none of the historical nihilists of whom I am aware believed this version. Certainly the Nazis, who loved The Will to Power, didn't. The anarchist-nihilists believed that they had to destroy the structure of society (over and over if necessary) in order to reach a utopia of the mind in which there would be no illusions, and in particular no domination of one group of people by another, but that is a mythic goal in itself. I think that the only people who can credibly be called nihilists in the sense suggested are catatonics. You can't ask them, so it's hard to tell.
